title: US breast cancer deaths have declined by 40% in 30 years
text:
Breast cancer killed 40 percent fewer American women in 2017 than it did in 1989, a new report reveals.

Despite this encouraging progress, not all women in the US are benefiting equally, the American Cancer Society researchers report.

Between 2016 and 2017, breast cancer surpassed lung cancer as the most deadly form of the disease for black women in six states: Arizona, Colorado, Florida, Georgia, Mississippi, and South Carolina.

And while the overall mortality rate continues to fall, that trend has slowed, suggesting efforts to prevent and catch breast cancer need to be re-doubled - especially for black women in the US.

Breast cancer death rates continue to decline in the US - but that progress has slowed since 2004 and the disease still disproportionately kills black women, according to a new report

The breast cancer death rate has been steadily declining for decades now.

Mammograms, chemo, radiation and immunotherapies have drastically improved doctors abilities to catch and treat breast cancer.

Yet in the last 15 years, more women have been developing the disease.

Since 2004, the number of women diagnosed with breast cancer has crept up by 0.3 percent every year, according to the new study.

That increase is driven primarily by one very particular type of breast cancer, called hormone receptor-positive (HR+) disease, the researchers say.

HR+ is a type of breast cancer that quickly metastisizes, or spreads, and is driven fueled by an excess of either of two hormones, estrogen or progesterone.

The new study's authors blame the spike in this subtype of cancer on rising rates of obesity and women who are overweight as well as declining rates of fertility - both trends that can boost levels of these hormones.

'We can't say for sure what the reasons are for the slowing of the decline in breast cancer mortality,' said Carol DeSantis, lead author of the report.

'It could be due in part to the slight increase in incidence since 2004, as well as a sign that optimal breast cancer treatment has become more widespread, particularly among white women.'

The good news is that HR+ breast cancer has a better overall survival rate, and rates of hormone receptor-negative breast cancer, which is deadlier, are falling.

Still, in 2019 an estimated 268,600 new cases of invasive breast cancer will be diagnosed in women in the US, the new study, published in CA: A Cancer Journal for Clinicians, reports.

And 41,760 women will die of breast cancer.

But since 1989, nearly 376,000 breast cancer deaths have been avoided thanks to preventative and treatment efforts.

Deaths continue to decline at a rate of about 1.3 percent per year - although that's a slow down from the nearly two percent annual declines seen between 1998 and 2011.

Largely due to poorer access to health care, minority women in the US have long faced higher mortality rates from breast cancer.

In the last fiver years, the US has made some progress in this disparity, broadly speaking.

Since 2013, the breast cancer death rate among black women has fallen by 1.5 percent a year and by 2.1 percent among Hispanic and Latina women, compared to one percent declines for white women.

Asians and Pacific Islanders have seen only a 0.8 percent decline, and numbers have stagnated among Native Americans and Alaska Natives.

Yet in Colorado and Wisconsin, deaths among black women, too, have leveled off. White women are consistently dying at the same rates in Nebraska, Texas and Virginia.

Although breast cancer is the most common cancer among women, lung is typically the most deadly form of the disease to them.

In most states, that remains true, but in Arizona, Colorado, Florida, Georgia, Mississippi and South Carolina breast cancer is now the top killer of black women.

Lung and breast cancer kill about the same number of black women in Alabama, Massachusetts, New York and Texas, the study authors report.

In Utah, breast cancer is the leading cause of cancer death for white women.

The report authors argue that there are complex factors driving the increases or slowing declines in death rates among certain populations.

They suggest that, at least in black women, contributing factors may be late-stage diagnoses, type of tumor, obesity and pre-existing conditions.
description: Breast cancer death rates have declined by 40% since 1989, but those declines have slowed to 1.3% per year, the American Cancer Society reports - and remain higher among black women.
